titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI. Change of wind in the Night to the Northwest— Morning cool. Dr Thornton came to repeat his application for the appointment of political Agent to Guatemala— With Mr Everett, heard at the Unitarian Church Mr Little from Judges, 17.13. [“]Then said Micah, Now know I that the Lord will do me good, seeing I have a Levite to my priest.” A Satirical Sermon, upon the Story of Micah— After church Mr Daniel Brent and Mr William Brent called upon me; the latter to recommend a Mr Radcliffe of New-York for the political mission to Guatemala— Attended alone the afternoon service at Mr Baker’s; and heard a stranger from 1. Corinthians 13.13. “And now abideth faith, hope, charity, these three; but the greatest of these is charity.” He made a very indifferent comment upon an admirable text.— Mr Bulfinch had invited Mr Everett and me to take tea with his family before the Evening service at Mr Little’s— We went accordingly; found judge Cranch there— Mr Little’s Evening text was from Luke 15.20. “And he arose, and came to his father. But when he was yet a great way off, his father saw him, and had compassion, and ran, and fell on his neck, and kissed him.”— The Story of the prodigal Son; and one of the best discourses I had ever heard from Mr Little— Returning home, I found Dr Watkins at my house.

2. VI:45.Mr G. Hay called this morning at my house, and enquired if there might be published in the National Journals a notice and abstract of the Convention with Russia, signed on the 17th. of April by Mr Middleton— I told him I had no objection, if the President should have none— Mr Wood the miniature Painter came, with B. O. Tyler, and finished the Portrait. Tyler is going off to-morrow for Albany, with a budget of his Presidential pictures for sale. At the Office Mr M. C. Patterson of New-York came for papers deposited in the Department of State, by the Florida Treaty Commission— I told him I had no authority to give out any of the original papers; but would furnish copies of such as might be wanted— A. B. Nones came to renew the application for the appointment of Consul at Maracaybo— I was at the President’s: found with him Captain James Barron, who is to be employed as Commander of the Navy Yard at Philadelphia— I spoke to the President of Instructions to be given to Mr Brown at Peru, with reference to a Resolution of H.R.U.S. at the close of the last Session of Congress. He directed a Cabinet Meeting for to-morrow at one O’Clock— The Instructions to the Florida-land-title
Commissioners occasion also much embarrassment. Mr Worthington having declined to accept his appointment— Instructions are likewise to be sent to Mr Middleton— The President is highly gratified with the Convention— But how it will be seen in the Senate is another affair— The President desired me to send immediately to the Secretary of the Navy, a Letter just received from T. Randall at the Havanna, containing an account of recent piracies. I sent it accordingly— Mr Southard goes upon his Northern tour to-morrow— Mr Preble came to the Office, to enquire after copies of papers to be obtained from Madrid— He goes to-morrow for Pittsburg— After dinner, with Mrs Adams, Mary Hellen, Ann M’Knight, Mr Everett, and my son John, we rode to Alexandria, and visited a garden of exotics kept there by a Quaker named Yates— Home about nine in the Evening. Addington at the Office.

3. V.Mr Everett, and Miss M’Knight left us this morning in the Stage for Baltimore with Commodore Chauncey and his family and Commodore Morris— Chauncey, who has been two or three years a Commissioner of the Navy, exchanges that situation for the command of the Navy-yard at New-York and is removing. Mr Southard the Secretary of the Navy likewise left the City with his family and Commodore Rodgers, going upon a tour of Inspection to the Northern navy yards— Mr G. Hay called at my house to tell me that the French Minister had arrived, and that as the President was desirous of returning as soon as possible to Loudoun, it would suit his convenience if I could present the Minister to him to-morrow— Mr Brent sent an intimation of this to the Count de Menou, who in consequence immediately sent a notification of the Minister’s arrival, with a request that I would receive him for which I appointed this day, at half past three— There was a Cabinet Meeting at the President’s at one— Mr Calhoun and Mr Wirt present— I had not been able to send a notification to Mr Crawford, as the President had desired. The principal question was of Instructions to be given to Mr Brown, for Negotiation with France, upon the claims of our Citizens; and whether he should be authorised to connect with it a negotiation for indemnity to France on account of the 5th. Article of the Louisiana Convention. After much discussion the President inclined to decide that we could not admit the blending of the two subjects, but deferred the decision till to-morrow, and requested me to notify Mr Crawford of the Meeting, and request his attendance if entirely convenient— Mr R. Forrest afterwards offered to go out and take himself the notification to Mr Crawford; which I requested him to do— Other subjects were also postponed till to-morrow— At half past three, the Baron Durand de Mareuil, came with the Count de Menou, and delivered to me the copy of his Credential Letter— He said he had also the answer to the notice of Mr Gallatin’s recall; and the notice of Baron Hyde de Neuville’s recall.
I informed him that the President would receive him at half past one to-morrow. Alexander Scott applied for the appointment of Agent to Guatemala— Dr Thornton was at my house this Evening.

4. V:30. Swam an hour with John and Antoine in the Potowmack. Visit from General Brown who has been at the Springs in Virginia, and intends returning there with his family— Linnaeus Smith was at the Office again, returned from Richmond— At one O’Clock I presented to the President the Baron Durand de Mareuil, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary from France— He delivered to the President his own Letter of Credence. The Letter of Notification of the Recall of the Baron Hyde de Neuville; and the Letter of Recredence for Mr Gallatin— The Baron made a very short Address to the President, assuring him of the friendly dispositions of the King of France towards the United States, and of his own earnest desire to promote the good understanding between the two Nations; which the President answered by assurances of reciprocal dispositions. He spoke also very kindly to the Count de Menou, who said he expected shortly to return to France, but hoped to pay his respects again to the President before his Departure. The Count was much affected by the President’s obliging expressions and warmly manifested his gratitude. The Cabinet Meeting was not held— Mr Crawford came in to the City, and was about an hour of the morning at the President’s, and then returned home. He told the President he had postponed departure for some days— I received this morning from Antonio Jose Cañaz, Envoy Extraordinary from the United Provinces of the Centre of America, a notification of his arrival, and as the President was extremely anxious to return to-morrow to Loudoun, he desired me, if possible, to get through the presentation of Mr Cañaz this day— Returning to the Office of the Department, I sent and requested him to call there immediately— It was so long before his lodgings were found that when he came it was past four O’Clock— He was accompanied by his Secretary of Legation, Mr Valero— Neither of them speaks English; and Mr Valero only very little French— They shewed me their Commission, of which I asked them to furnish me copies— I went with them immediately to the President, and presented them— Mr Cañaz delivered his Credential Letter but made no speech— The President assured him of the friendly feeling of the United States towards his Country— After an early dinner I attended at the President’s, where the deputations of Indians had their second conference— They were now all dressed in the clothing furnished them here. Short speeches were made again to them by the President, and by him to them in return. Medal’s were distributed to all the Chiefs. Several of them earnestly pressed their wishes to be dismissed, and to return home. Mrs Adams
and John were there— Also Mr Wirt’s family— Old Mrs Calhoun, and two of his children— The French Minister and Consul and their families— And some others— The President gave the medals, suspending them over the necks of the Chiefs— Presents were also made to the Squaws and children— One of the Piankeshaws who acted as interpreter from one Dialect, to another was very ill, with a high fever— Between 8 and 9 it was over— I asked the President’s directions upon various points; but he was not prepared to give them. On returning home I found Laborie at my house— He comes out as Secretary of Legation to the Baron de Mareuil— Judge Woodward and Dr Watkins were afterwards here— Mr R. Cutts, second Comptroller had been here last Evening; complaining of an interference by Mr Calhoun with an official decision of his in favor of the claim of D. Parker upon the grant of Congress to the Estate of J. H. Piatt. I advised him to see the President.

5. V:15. Swam an hour in the Potowmack, alone; but the morning was cool, and the remonstrances of my friends against the continuance of this practice will induce me to abandon it; perhaps altogether— Mr Lemuel Sawyer formerly a member of Congress, called upon me with a subscription Book, for the publication of a Tragedy, in five Acts, entitled the Wreck of Honour by him— He has already published a Comedy in four Acts, called Blackbeards— At the Office A. B. Nones came and took his Commission as Consul at Marocaybo— The Count de Menou called, to enquire if the list to be furnished of the Baron de Mareuil’s Legation should include those who were of the French Legation before— I thought it should. The Count told me how much he had been affected by the kind expressions yesterday of the President to him— Dr Watkins called at the Office— Mr G. Hay called at my house after dinner, and we walked—called at C. B. King’s the Painter’s; and saw the Portraits he is painting of the Indians now here— Mrs Adams rode with Dr Huntt to Mrs French’s at Georgetown, to see Mrs W. S. Smith who is residing there. Mr Anderson the Comptroller of the Treasury was also this morning at my Office— To enquire of the Construction of the Act of Congress of Feby 1823, concerning the commercial intercourse with the British Colonies in America. His question was whether a British vessel from a Colony in North-America could proceed to a Colony in the West-Indies, and vice versa— I told him they could— He had also a question whether in Massachusetts a man could be held to Bail on mesne process, without an Oath of the Plf to the debt. I said he could unless the Law had been lately changed— I had also much conversation with him upon the Politics of former times; particularly of the embargo of 1807— He was a member of the Committee of the Senate which reported that Bill.

6. VI. Cool morning— No bath. Mr T. Findlay of Baltimore called upon me, and had a long conversation upon political subjects with me. He is very anxious upon the issue of the Presidential Election; and much more sangwine than the circumstances will warrant— Mr Slade came to ask a leave of absence for a few weeks, on a visit to Vermont— Mr Frye, with a Letter from Mr Ringgold at Savannah, concerning the Lands to which the Heirs of Joshua Johnson have claims in Georgia— At the Office without interruption— Wrote a few short Letters— Walk after dinner; part solitary— Evening visits from Mr Laborie, the Count de Ganay, attached to the new French Legation, and from W. Lee.

7. VI.Mr T. Findlay of Baltimore called again and had a long conversation with me; on the prospects of the Election. He has conversed freely with Mr Calhoun, and endeavoured to impress upon him the necessity of union, between his friends; those of General Jackson and mine. He says Calhoun cares nothing about the Vice-Presidency, but thinks it not yet time for Jackson to withdraw— Mr Frye was here, and read to me the draft of a Letter to Ringgold, about the Georgia Lands. Mr Cañaz the Minister, and Mr Valero the Secretary of Legation from Guatemala, paid us visits— At the Office I was without interruption; and despatched a Letter with enclosures to the President— Walk with Mrs. Adams after dinner.

8. V:30. Swam with John and Antoine an hour in the Potowmack. I kept almost entirely within my depth— John and Mary Hellen, went to the Methodist camp Meeting about six Miles from the City. Heard Mr Little in the Morning from Luke 21.19.— “In your patience possess ye your Souls.”— A text to which I have often, and with the deepest earnestness of mind had recourse— The Sermon addressed itself to me, not less forcibly than the text— Self-controul in trying Seasons, is the most necessary of all properties; and never was it more needed for me, in the whole course of my life—perhaps never near so much— In the afternoon I heard a discourse from Mrat Mr Baker’s, from Acts 24.16. “And herein do I exercise myself, to have always a conscience void of Offence toward God, and toward men.” This also was a lesson of instruction, and I cannot have too many of them; but it was not so pungent as that of the morning— In the interval between the services, I had visited with Mrs Adams the Baron and Baroness de Mareuil; at Williamson’s Hotel— Mr T. Finlay was gone— E. Wyer dined with us— In the Evening I heard Mr Little again, from Acts 16.29.30.31. “Then he
called for a Light, and sprang in, and came trembling, and fell down before Paul and Silas— And brought them out, and said, sirs, what must I do to be saved?— And they said Believe on the Lord Jesus Christ, and thou shalt be saved, and thy house.”— This was a doctrinal discourse; explaining the text so that it may not support the system of Salvation by faith alone— I this day received despatches from J. M. Forbes, announcing the death of C. A. Rodney, Minister at Buenos-Ayres, on the 10th. of June— From H. Allen, in Chili, giving an account of his reception there; and from H. Dearborn at Lisbon with information that he had taken leave of the King. 1. July, and should embark in a few days for Boston.

9. V:30. Swam an hour with John and Antoine— Judge Woodward was at my house— Long conversation with him— I told him I thought it doubtful whether the President would send any more Ministers to South-America; and observed that his principal object was to wind up his Administration— At the Office came Jeremy Robinson, still soliciting compensation for past services and employment for the future— G. B. English had been at my house, also to enquire what he was to do? And Wyer called to say nothing— He had been here yesterday with Mr Houston. Mr G. Hay was here in the Evening— There was a thunder shower; but not much rain. Dr Watkins was likewise this morning at my Office. I received a Letter from James Tallmadge at Albany; where the New-York Legislature after a Session of five days, were to adjourn on the 6th. leaving parties, as much undecided as ever, and a victory claimed on both sides— The first number of the Daily National Journal came out this day—very unexpectedly to me— Mr Crawford left the City this morning.

10. V. Swam an hour in the Potowmack, with John— At the Office. P. D. Stelle came to solicit employment for his Son— Mr Addington; going upon an excursion to the Bedford Springs, for three weeks— He sent me this morning several papers of complaint against Harvey Strong, late Consul at Glasgow— I told him that Mr Walker had been appointed Consul there in Strong’s place, with which he was much pleased— He spoke also of the complaint against Captain Porter and Lieutt. Gregory, for the challenge— I told him the papers were with the President— The Baron de Mareuil and the Count de Menou likewise called; but upon no special business— The Baron is upon the lookout for a dwelling-house— A person from New-Jersey by the name of Flat, came on a visit of mere curiosity— Walk after dinner. Evening calls from Mr Laborie, Dr and Mrs Thornton, and Mrs Talbot. T. Bulfinch had been this morning at the Office, and promised to come to-morrow morning, and settle N. Read’s Note.

11. V:30. Intermitted my Potowmack Baths— T. Bulfinch called at my house and settled N. Read’s Note— At the Office, Mr Swift of Alexandria, Consular Agent for Sweden, came to make application in behalf of the Captain of the Swedish vessel seized at New-Orleans, for importing brandy, in casks of illegal size— There is a petition from the Captain to the Secretary of the Treasury for remission of the forfeiture on the ground of ignorance of the Law— But the Petition should be to the District Judge, who must report to the Secretary of the Treasury— The Office of District judge however, in Louisiana is vacant; and the Law has made no provision for the case— I referred Mr Swift finally to that Comptroller of the Treasury, Mr Anderson, but told him I was apprehensive the Secretary had no authority to act in the case— I received a Letter from H. Wheaton— Dined with John at Baron Tuyll’s— A Diplomatic dinner, given to the Baron de Mareuil— In the Evening I called at Gadsby’s to return the visits of Mr Cañaz, and Mr Valero, the Minister and Secretary of Legation from Guatemala, but they had just left the house— Evening at Mr Frye’s. Mrs Adams was there— Walk alone home.

12. V:30. Morning undisturbed— Letter from P.U.S.Wyer and Watkins at the Office— Ride after dinner with Mrs Adams— Walk with G. Hay, who afterwards passed an hour with me— He told me that the President had lately received an anonymous Letter, in a disguised hand and affecting false spelling, but undoubtedly from an able hand, advising him to dismiss all the members of his Administration, except Mr Crawford— Calhoun because he is presumptuous, and extravagant. Southard; to go and keep School in New-Jersey— Wirt, because he is treacherous, and no real friend to Mr Monroe; and me, because I despise his abilities.— Hay said he did not consider Mr Crawford as a member of the Administration at-all—and he persists in thinking his state of health desperate— This is prejudice—

13. V. A Mr Gideon Davis of Georgetown brought me a Letter from G. Johnson. He has invented a stove for warming rooms, of which he brought with him a small model— It is a contrivance for carrying the air heated by the fire in the stove through a flew fixed into plank raised an inch or two above the floor of the room, so that it may come in to the room at the floor. He seemed desirous of communicating his invention to the Public, through the means of the Columbian Institute—
I recommended to him to take out a Patent; but to this he was not inclined. I then advised him to send to the Institute a description of his invention, and a model, which might be referred to a Committee who might report upon them, and the report might be published. He said he would— At the Office, Mr Calhoun called with a Letter from B. Cozzens to Lemuel Williams; to solicit the appointment of District Attorney for Rhode Island. Calhoun is going next week upon an excursion into Pennsylvania— Wyer also was at the Office— I finished the draft of a Report to the House of Representatives, upon the Petition of Pelatiah Fitch— To be presented at their next Session. Ride after dinner with Mrs Adams, and then returned the visit of Mr Cañaz, the Minister, from Guatemala— Time still wasted.

14. V:15. I received this day a Letter from John Rutherfurd, who from 1791. to 1799 was a member of the Senate of the United States in New-Jersey; enclosing in confidence a rough draft of a Letter from him to Theodore Sedgwick, then a Senator from Massachusetts, dated 27. Feby 1799. and Sedgwick’s answer dated 1. March of the same year, relating to the appointment of Ministers to France. He sends them to me, supposing me to be preparing a reply to the late pamphlet of Timothy Pickering, which partly relates to this subject— Wyer and Watkins were at the Office, and G. Hay to inform me that he should go to-morrow to Oakhill to the President. I wrote a short Letter to the President, and enclosed to him sundry papers. Solitary walk after dinner. Mrs Adams unwell this Evening.

15. V:30. Heard Mr Little, this morning from Job. 35.10.11. “But none saith, where is God my maker, who giveth songs in the night;—who teacheth us more than the beasts of the earth, and maketh us wiser than the fowls of heaven?” a discourse upon the dignity of the human species, and their superiority over all other animals. Exemplified by the mention of the mariner’s compass, and that of printing.— Mr Little gave notice that we was going upon an excursion for some weeks— In the afternoon, Mr Baker preached from 2. Chronicles 32.25. “But Hezekiah rendered not again according to the benefit done unto him; for his heart was lifted up:”— Dr Thornton went with me in the Evening and heard Mr Little from 1. Corinthians 3.10–15. “For other foundation can no man lay than that is laid, which is Jesus Christ.” &c He said this was one of a number of discourses, chiefly extemporaneous, which he has lately delivered, to prove unitarian doctrines from texts chiefly relied upon by their adversaries— Mr R. Cutts and Dr Watkins paid us evening visits.

16. V:15.Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General called at my House this morning— He returned yesterday from his tour to Saratoga— He says that De Witt Clinton thinks the Majority of the New-York Legislature will choose a ticket of 36 electors who will vote for Mr Crawford. That a number sufficient to make the majority will be bought with money; and that the same men might be bought with money, for any purpose and by any purchaser— Even a foreign power— He said this distinctly to M’Lean himself— Now DeWitt Clinton ought well to know the people of New-York, and their Legislature— He has himself applied for his own advancement to the Presidency so much money, as to have ruined his own fortunes. He has therefore no scruple against the use of money, for that purpose and has perhaps in former times, bought some of the very individuals of whom he now speaks thus— I hope better things; and believe that corruption has not yet quite arrived at that pitch— That the Legislature of New-York will sell the suffrage of the State, I think it more than probable and must find satisfaction in the certainty that it will not be sold to me— Wyer called at the Office— N. Frye came to ask me to go tomorrow with Mrs Adams to the City Hall, and acknowledge before the Mayor, the power of Attorney for recovering the Georgia Lands— Solitary Evening walk— Laborie brought me a Letter from the French Minister, stating some difficulty to the landing of his wines, at the Navy-Yard, from a Schooner to which they had with the rest of his effects been transshipped, from the Corvette in which he arrived at Norfolk— I promised to see that the difficulty should be removed to-morrow Morning— Answered General H. A. S. Dearborn’s Letter, and finished at the Office the draft of Instructions to the Commissioners of Land-titles at St. Augustine.

17. V:30. I called this morning on the Comptroller of the Treasury, Mr Anderson, and requested of him an order for the free entrance of the effects of the French Minister, including his wines; which he assured me should immediately be despatched. I went with Mrs Adams and Mr and Mrs Frye, to the City-Hall, and there acknowledged before the Mayor Saml. N. Smallwood the Power of Attorney to Mr Frye, for the recovery of the Georgia Lands— At the Office, the Baron de Tuyll, the Russian minister came to ask a question of Etiquette— Whether at the dinner at my house to which he is invited to-morrow, the Minister of Guatimala, as a new comer, as well as the Baron de Mareuil, the French Minister would take precedence of him; I said no— That the French Minister having first arrived, the dinner
was given to him, and to his Lady— That the Minister from Guatemala, having afterwards arrived would be of the party; but would not take precedence of any Minister of the same rank— That the only place at which there was any Etiquette of Foreign Ministers as to place, was the President’s— None at my house— And as the Minister from Guatemala, speaks no French, and is not acquainted with Madame Durant St. André I should request him Baron Tuyll, to lead her to the dinner Table— He said in that case he would with pleasure attend, but otherwise should have desired to write me a note, excusing himself on the ground of a slight indisposition from attending. All this was with many professions that neither he nor his Court cared any thing about Etiquette— Wyer was at the Office— Walking after dinner I met William Lee, who walked home with me, and came in and took tea— General La Fayette arrived, below New-York Sunday Morning. Landed and spent the day at the Vice Presidents, at Staten-Island.

18. V:15.Charles’s birth day. 17. Answered James Tallmadge’s Letters. At the Office— Wrote to the President—Wyer at the Office; and Mr Bernabeu Consul of Spain at Baltimore; a place which he held for many years; and to which after having been removed in consequence of the late revolution in Spain, he has now been restored— We had company to dine— The Baron Durant de Mareuil and his Lady, Mr. and Madame Durant St. André, the Counts de Menou and Ganay, Messrs.De Bresson, Laborie, D’Espinville, Thierry and Sontag, all belonging to the French Legation or Consulate, Baron de Tuyll, Russian Minister and Maltitz, Secretary to the Legation, Mr Cañas, Minister and Mr Valero, Secretary of Legation from the Republic of the Centre of America, or Guatemala, Mr Parish attached to the British Legation, Mr Rebello, Chargé d’Affaires from Brazil, and Mr Daniel Brent— The difficulty of bringing together the Ministers of the great European Powers, and the Representatives of the new American Governments, was again got over on the occasion; and the dinner passed off, without dissatisfaction in any quarter— After eight or ten cool days the heat of Summer has again returned.

19. V: Swam with John in the Potowmack, about half an hour. The tide low, and rapidly going out, weather a flat calm— Dr Watkins called upon me with Nathl. Williams of Baltimore; a Candidate for the appointment of District judge for that District— The late judge Theodorick Bland having been appointed Chancellor of the State of Maryland— Isaac Munroe, Editor of the Baltimore Patriot called at the Office, and brought a recommendation signed by several respectable persons in favor of Mr Williams— Munroe is
also a warm electioneering person, and seemed surprized to find me so much less sanguine then himself— Wyer came also to the Office and dined with us, as did Mr and Mrs Frye, Robert and Lloyd Buchanan and little Tom Frye— Mr Wirt called in the Evening, and said much of the appointment of a District judge in Maryland, but without expressing a decisive opinion, in favor of any one— Received through Baron Tuyll, a dispatch from R. Rush of 5. July last.

20. V. Swam with John and Antoine an hour and 25 minutes. I landed at the Point. Mr T. Bulfinch called at my house, with a Letter to me, and a correspondence between him and Mr Elgar the Commissioner of the Public Buildings— There is a difference of opinion between them concerning the laying of flues in the floor of the Rotundo at the Capitol for warming the central part of the Building— Bulfinch wished me to settle the question by giving my opinion to Elgar, in favor of the flues. But I concluded to refer the question and the papers to the President. Mr A. B. Woodward came with a Letter from Joseph L. Smith U.S. judge at St. Augustine— Mentioning the death of W. W. Blair recently appointed judge of the central district of Florida, and urging Woodward to apply for the appointment, which he did. Mr Smallwood the Mayor of the City, Mr Daniel Carroll of Duddington, and Commodore Tingey came as a subcommittee from the Corporation, to enquire what arrangements the President had made or proposed to make, for the reception of General La Fayette— So that those of the Corporation might harmonize with them— I told them that I had not heard from the President, since the General’s arrival— That he had told me before, that he intended to invite him to reside while here at the Presidential house; and I advised them to go and confer with the President himself at Oakhill— Isaac Munroe called; intending to return this Evening to Baltimore— At the Office, Mr Hodgson came and took his translations of the Constitutions of Brazil and of Chile, for publication— I recommended to him a previous revisal of them— John Mitchell came, to request an allowance of some old charges standing against him at the Treasury into which I promised to enquire— Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General, to ask about my votes on the Louisiana Treaty and the Cumberland road— I shewed him in the National Intelligencer ofNovember 1803 my speech on the Bill making the appropriations
for carrying the Treaty into effect, of which he desired to have a copy— Evening idle. Johnson Hellen came in from Bedford— Mr Darrell called also this morning at the Office, to enquire of the appointment of a Consul at Batavia, and was much disappointed at learning that Mr Shillaber had been appointed.

21. V:15. Swam in the Potowmack with John an hour and 10 minutes. the tide going out but not very rapidly— The day was of great summer heat with a Southwest wind, which is our Sirocco. Mr John Thomas came and exhibited to me a wheel Saw, which he has just invented for sawing off the Snags, Sawyers and Planters in the Mississippi river— Thomas talks Politics too and Electioneering more than is altogether agreeable. Especially as he knows very little about what he talks of— A Mr Samuel Plummer came from Alexandria with a recommendation from Judge Cranch, and soliciting employment in the Department; for the obtaining of which I could give no encouragement. At the Office, I received a very singular Letter from the Baron Hyde de Neuville now French Ambassador in Portugal; brought by General Dearborn who has arrived at Boston— The Baron de Mareuil likewise called, and left a Letter for the President, also from the Baron Hyde de Neuville. He has not yet received his Instructions for discussing the question of the stopping of the Frigate with H. Nelson on board, our Minister to Spain at the entrance of the Harbour of Cadix— Wyer was at the Office— Solitary walk after dinner— Heat oppressive— Laborie here this Evening.

22. V. Heard Mr Baker; this morning from Acts 26.28. “Then Agrippa said unto Paul, almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian.” And in the afternoon from Job 13.23. “Make me to know my transgression and my sin.” He preached again in the Evening at the foundery Methodist Church, but I did not attend— Mrs Adams went this Morning with Madame de Mareuil to St. John’s Church— She is a German Lutheran. The day was intensely warm, and my loss of time was proportionably great— I received, and answered a Letter from H. V. Somerville. This morning, I swam an hour and a quarter with John and Antoine. Evening from dinner time, idleness absolute.

23. V:30. Swam an hour and ten minutes with John. The tide just turning; and we went towards the point; out to a boat, anchored for fishing near the middle of the river— Mr Robert Easter called and I took his note, upon interest for 180 dollars which he was bound to pay on the ninth of this Month, on his Mortgage of 8. August 1823. At the Office a Mr. Chew
came upon a claim for a Slave carried away by the British in 1813 or 1814. with very defective evidence— A Mr M’Gregor to solicit employment in the Department— Mr Cazenove of Alexandria, with his son, just returned from Europe— Baron Tuyll the Russian Minister had written this morning to request an interview, and came at two O’Clock, the hour appointed. He had received despatches from his Government, by the Count de Medem, whom he asked to introduce to me; for which I appointed two O’Clock to-morrow. The Baron has received Powers and Instructions to treat concerning the indemnities to be allowed to the owners of the Pearl; but still with a protestation against the principle upon which they are demanded— The Baron expressed a strong apprehension of a possible opposition to the Convention in the Senate; which he said after the sacrifices made by the Emperor in the way of conciliation would be extremely painful— I told him that I did not expect there would be opposition; but if there should, its object will be here and not in Russia— He said he was aware of that; but that it would nevertheless, not fail to be felt— He read me an extract from a despatch upon the subject of the confidential communications between him and me of last winter— It expressed the satisfaction of the Emperor at the conciliatory disposition manifested by them on our part, notwithstanding our explicit avowal of opposite principles— The Baron read to me also a despatch from Count Nesselrode of 20. May, 1. June explanatory of a certificate of good conduct which he had furnished L. Harris at his solicitation, and a copy of which was enclosed with the despatch— The two papers were not of congenial purport— The despatch speaking of Harris in terms very different from those of the certificate— I asked the Baron if he had any objection to furnishing me copies of both— He said the whole communication was confidential— That he would furnish me a copy of the certificate; but could not of the despatch. But he allowed me to read it a second time, and observing that I read it with much attention, he asked if I had any particular reason for it—I told him I had given depositions to be used in the Law-suit to which those papers referred— That my testimony had not been favourable to Mr Harris, and that I had no doubt he had obtained this certificate with a view to its operating to discredit my testi-
mony— The certificate is altogether in general terms, and states that Mr Harris in his conduct as a public agent of the United States had given entire satisfaction to the Russian Government— That he had been in part the founder of the relations between the two Countries, and that he had obtained special marks of confidence from the predecessor of the Minister of foreign affairs Count Nesselrode— The despatch states, that in the Law-suit between Harris and Lewis, which had acquired a too deplorable celebrity, both parties had applied to the Russian Government for copies of official documents. That Mr Harris having arrived there had been treated with the attentions due to a person who had previously held a public office under a foreign Nation, and discharged it to the satisfaction of the Emperor— But that with regard to his lawsuit, and his possible prevarications in reference to his own Countrymen, the Russian Government could consider him only as a private individual, and felt its duty to be to observe an entire impartiality between the parties— That when Mr Harris had applied for copies of public documents he had been informed they could be furnished only upon the application of the Minister of the United States, and would upon the same application be furnished to the adverse party— That accordingly Mr Middleton had applied for copies of documents for Mr Lewis which had been furnished— That Mr Harris had been irritated at this, and whether from vanity or from personal animosity had not applied for his documents through Mr Middleton; though if he had they would have been furnished him— But he had solicited the certificate of good conduct, which as relating to mere general considerations it had been thought proper to give him; and the Baron was apprized of all these Circumstances that he might use them as occasion should require if Mr Harris should seek to give a particular colouring to the refusal to furnish copies of Documents to him, in any other manner than as they were furnished to Mr Lewis.— I told Baron Tuyll that Harris did not want the Documents for which he applied; but wanted to avail himself of the refusal of them— Mr W. H. Allen came and received the Instructions and Documents for the East-Florida Land-title Commissioners. He took leave and is to go off to-morrow Morning— W. Lee, and Dr Watkins were at the Office; and Laborie paid us an Evening visit.

24. V:15. Swam with John; to the Boat at anchor; then to the point at the Mouth of the Tyber; and back to my Rock, in an hour and a quarter. Mr Charles Yancey of Richmond came to say he was an applicant for the appointment of Postmaster there, vacated by the Death of Dr Foushee. He came with my neighbour Wheaton, and shewed me a confidential Letter from the President to him dated in December 1822.
I advised him to apply to the Postmaster General, and shew him the Letter from the President, and then to go to the President himself at Oakhill— He came afterwards again and told me he had seen the Postmaster General, and shewn him the President’s Letter— Mr M’Lean told him he had written to the President concerning the appointment, and should take his advice in filling it. Yancey said he would go to the President’s— He also told me there was a Mr John Nicholas at Richmond, who had written some political speculations, in which my name was introduced; which he wished to have published in the National Journal; and he desired to enquire if he might enclose them under cover to me— I said there might be some impropriety in that, and asked why he could not address them to Force himself, the Editor of the Journal— He said Ritchie, of the Enquirer, Foushee’s son in Law had intelligences at the Post Office, and a controul over it— Nicholas did not like to trust a communication addressed to Force, to it— But he said he would send it to Wheaton, under cover to the Commissioner of the Land-Office— George Johnson came, and we cancelled our Articles of Agreement executed last year, and left the property wholly at my disposal— We agreed that he should continue to have the management of the Mills for the ensuing year as my Agent, and he will call again to-morrow to execute an agreement to that effect— Mr D. Brent called; I had intended to leave the City the day after to morrow, for Quincy, but at the President’s desire have postponed my departure till next week— I had a morning visit also from Coll. Bomford— At the Office. Baron Tuyll came and introduced the Count de Medem to me, who also brought Letters of warm recommendation from Mr Poletica; and from W. Lewis. The Baron told me Count Medem was also earnestly recommended to him from the Department of Foreign Affairs—that he was going on a tour to New-York and Boston and into Canada; and he asked Letters for him which I promised. The Baron brought me a copy of the certificate given by Count Nesselrode to L. Harris; and spoke again about the ratification of the North-west Coast Convention, concerning which he is extremely anxious— He asked me, if I thought it would be of use, if he should write to Mr Gallatin concerning it— I told him I thought not. If Mr Gallatin should come here before the meeting of Congress, he might freely converse with him concerning it— But I did not apprehend any opposition to the Convention from Mr Gallatin. Nor if he should write to him
would Mr Gallatin, interfere in its favour— He would answer him politely, and resort to commonplace remarks of his being now only a private Citizen, and leave the Convention just as he found it— He said he would not write to him— Jeremy Robinson was at the Office with renewal of solicitations. I wrote to the President and sent William Maul, as an Express to him with my Letter— Walk after dinner with Mrs Adams. We had Evening visits, from the Baron and Baroness de Mareuil— The Count de Ganay, Messrs. de Bresson, D’Espinville, Sontag and Laborie— Music of the Piano, and singing by Ganay and Sontag. Late Evening.

25. V:30. Swam across the Potowmack, with John— Antoine crossing at the same time in a Boat, close at hand to take us in, had we met any insuperable difficulty. I was exactly an hour and a half from shore to shore. John was ten minutes less—we passed through thick grass in several places; but the tide was a spring tide at its full, and the water so high that we got thro’. We returned in the boat. Antoine swam about half the way back, but got so entangled in the weeds that he was obliged to get into the boat; but the Water was not over his head— I landed, returning at the point at the Mouth of the Tyber— We had been from home nearly four hours— The distance across the Potowmack is upwards of a Mile.— George Johnson came, and we executed a new Agreement for the Management of the Mills for the present year— The first has been a total and a severe disappointment; and I have no reason to expect any thing better from the second— John Mitchell came again to the Office, about the charges in account against him, for which I referred him to Mr Brent— Evening walk alone; then visits from Dr and Mrs Thornton, and Mrs Talbot— I wrote to F. March, at Madeira, to demand the delivery of three piratical murderers detained there. I had also a visit this morning from Mr Eaton—the Senator from Tennessee. He has been northward since the close of the Session of Congress; and is now going home.

26. V:30. Swam alone, to the Bridge, and returned; passing under the draw—fifty minutes in the water. Mrs Adams, Johnson and Mary Hellen and John left the City this morning in a Hack for Baltimore. Mrs. Adams is going to spend a week at Mr Hopkinsons at Bordentown. Johnson goes upon a matrimonial adventure to Baltimore. Mr C. Bulfinch called for an answer respecting his controversy with Elgar. I told him that I had sent the Papers to the President— My Messenger William Maul returned from Oakhill; and said the President had directed him to tell me he had written me by the last Mail, and would
write me again by the mail of this day— I received a Letter, and packet of Papers from the President. He mentioned that he had written to Mr Wirt for his opinion concerning the appointment of District judge in Maryland, and directed me to confer with him— I called at Mr Wirt’s Office— He had answered the President and recommended John Purviance; but said the President would not appoint him, because he was a federalist— I had other conversation with Mr Wirt—speculative and political— At my own Office Mr H. Parish called to request from Mr Addington an answer to his Letters of complaint against Commodore Porter, and Lieutt. Gregory— And the Baron de Mareuil; to mention a new work upon natural history; a sequel to Buffon’s Birds—of which he was directed to present us a copy, in exchange for one of Wilson’s Ornithology. E. Wyer dined with me— In the Evening I went to the Washington Assembly Rooms, and saw performed two Acts of Douglas by the Washington Dramatic Society— The heat then drove me home—

27. V:30. Swam with Antoine to and from the Bridge— The same as I had done yesterday; but this morning I was an hour and 25 minutes in going through the distance, I had yesterday traversed in 50 minutes. This difference was owing to the different state of the tide, which was running this morning so much more rapidly than yesterday. Last summer when the tides were so strong I desisted from the attempt to reach the Bridge, which I now find I can accomplish; but it takes as much time, as crossing the river at full tide, and is more fatiguing. Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General called at my house— I gave him a copy of my speech on the Louisiana Appropriation Bill 3. Novr. 1803— He said he thought the President would recommend, the appointment of Governor Preston as Postmaster at Richmond— Mr Yancey afterwards came, and told me, the President had thus determined. He gave me a Letter from the President, recommending him warmly and expressing regret that he could not promote his application for the Post-Office— At the Office A. B. Woodward called and received his commission as judge for the middle district of Florida— Dr. Watkins shewed me a Letter from a Mr Browner, one of the Candidates as an Editor of President and Vice-President in Maryland, which gives a particular account of the exertions making by the partizans both of Mr
Crawford and of General Jackson to slander me, and run down my reputation. There is a common chime to the same purpose in all the Presses devoted to Crawford, and in several devoted to Jackson. About fifteen newspapers in various parts of the United States, several of them daily papers, others printed twice or three times a week are, and for the ensuing four or five Months at least will be filled, column upon column, with every thing that truth, misrepresentation or falsehood can supply to defame and disgrace me— In passing through this ordeal may the Spirit which has hitherto sustained me, still be my staff and guide. E. Wyer dined with me— In the Evening there was a very short but severe thunder shower.

28. V:30. Swam alone; to the Bridge and back, in an hour and 25 minutes, against a strong tide, much the same as yesterday.— This is the tenth day in succession, of my Potowmack Baths, with the morning tides— Five days before the New-Moon, the day of the New Moon, and four days after— It was probably my last bath in the Potowmack, at least if I should go next week upon my Eastern tour— For on my return the bathing Season will be past, and I shall probably never pass another Summer in this City— Mr D. Brent called at my house, and mentioned the catastrophe of last Evening, when a brick wall at the end of a house was struck with lightening or cast down by the gust, and falling upon the roof of a small adjoining wooden house, so crushed it that two men in it were killed and several other persons very severely wounded— Judge Woodward came and left with me several papers for my perusal— Alexander Scott, of Georgetown who conversed upon scientific topics, Hyena Caves, safety lamps and the chemical composition of the Earth— Mr M’Lean the Postmaster General came, and introduced to me judge M’Kee of Kentucky, who brought me a Letter of Introduction from George Robertson— They have just gone through their Elections, and the relief party have prevailed over the Court party; or in other words the debtors over the Creditors— Among the rest John Pope has lost his Election to the State Legislature—and Rowan is to come into the Senate, in the place of Talbot— A Mr D. T. Blake of New-York brought me Letters of recommendation from H. Wheaton, and C. King— He came as an applicant for the appointment of judge in the middle District of Florida, but it was already made— At the Office I received a Letter from the President stating that he would be here this day or to-morrow— Returning home I met Mr Rankin of Mississippi just from Bedford and Berkley Springs— Saw Mr Crawford who has derived great benefit from the Bath Waters, and will remain there some time longer— Rankin wished the appointment of Marshal in the District of Mississippi, might be for some time postponed, and did not know whom
to recommend— Dr Watkins and Mr Yancey dined with me. In that Evening I received a Message from the President; that he had arrived in the City and would see me to-morrow Morning.

29. V:30. Heard Mr Baker this Morning from Habakkuk 3.2. “Oh Lord revive thy work”—intended as an argument in favour of what are called revivals of religion— And in the afternoon Mr Balch of Georgetown from Acts 2.42. “And they continued stedfastly in the apostles doctrine and fellowship, and in breaking of bread, and in prayers”— Mr Balch’s Sermon was extemporaneous and discursive— My Son John returned from Philadelphia, having left his mother and Mary Hellen going to Bordentown— E. Wyer dined with us— In the Evening I wrote Letters of Introduction for Count Medem— I had passed an hour of the morning with the President; conversing upon various subjects of public concernment— Our relations with the European Powers—Russia, Great-Britain—France— Those with South-America, and upon the question whether appointments shall now be made to Buenos-Ayres and Mexico, and an Agent to Guatemala—or whether they shall all be postponed— I told him the substance of my Conversations lately with Baron Tuyll, at the purport of which he expressed much Satisfaction— He approved particularly the observations I had made upon the Baron’s enquiry, whether it would be advisable for him to write to Mr Gallatin concerning the North-west Coast Convention— He said that he did not suspect Mr Gallatin would make any improper use of such a Letter; but he would perhaps endeavour to turn it to his account: he would communicate it to his political friends and supporters, and then it would be under their controul and not his— As to the appointment of a district judge in Maryland, his impressions were as Mr Wirt had supposed they would be— Purviance’s federalism is a stumbling block; not as to the President’s own Sentiments—but as to the effect upon public opinion—but he directed a meeting with Mr Wirt, at one, to-morrow.

30. V:30. Second day of rain. Mr Yancey called on me two or three times this morning. He had a lingering hope that the President would recommend him instead of General Preston for the Post-Office at Richmond; upon discovering that it was less profitable than had been expected, and he procured a Certificate from the Deputy Post-master
Bradley, of the proceeds for the last three years, amounting to no more than between 7 and 800 dollars a year. He requested me to give this to the President, which I did, but his determination for the appointment of Preston was not shaken— Dr Thornton had left with me yesterday an electioneering paper which he had written, and proposed to send and have distributed as hand-bills, to the number of 1500 in the State of New-York. It was an argument against the Election of Mr Crawford as President, founded upon the violent papers of the Georgia delegation, about the Cherokee Indians, at the last Session of Congress, and of the Governor of Georgia, Troup; then and since. Thornton’s argument is from the character of these papers to the danger of choosing a Citizen of Georgia for President— I told the Dr that I wished he would not publish that paper; for it was within my knowledge, that Mr Crawford had disapproved of those papers of the Georgia Delegation, and had endeavoured to prevail upon them to take them back— I could therefore not approve of the publication of any paper which would represent Mr Crawford as responsible for them— The Dr took away his paper, but brought it again this morning with an additional paragraph, stating that Mr Crawford as the writer had been since preparing the paper had been informed, had disapproved of the Georgia Delegation remonstrances; and then proceeding with an argument that Mr Crawford’s disapprobations had not been sincere— I told the Dr that this was worse than it had been before; and very strongly remonstrated against his making the publication at-all— Mr G. B. English came again to urge the necessity of appointing him to go out immediately to Gibraltar; to negotiate with the Capitan Pasha; to save the American property at Smyrna, from seizure and confiscation by the Turks in consequence of the subscriptions from the United States, in aid of the Greeks. I referred him to the President— At one O’Clock I attended at the President’s, and met Mr Wirt there— The discussion was upon the propriety of making an immediate appointment of Ministers to Mexico and Buenos-Ayres and of an Agent to Guatemala; and concerning the appointment of a District Judge, and District Attorney in Maryland— The President himself strongly inclined, and has certainly been urged to make the appointments to South-America; but I thought it would be best to wait until October and perhaps even till the meeting of Congress before making any of them. I said the effort made at the last Session of Congress to reduce the Missions to South-America, would certainly be renewed at the next; and
probably with success— If Ministers should be now appointed, it was highly probable the appropriations to continue them would be desired, and then it would assume the appearance of a reduction achieved as a victory over the Administration— The President said he had been ardently pressed to make immediately the appointment to Mexico—on the argument that a Minister from the United-States would ensure the failure of Yturbide’s new imperial expedition, which would otherwise succeed— In this I had no faith; and the President determined finally to postpone all the appointments to those Missions— Mr Wirt was very desirous that J. Purviance should be appointed District Judge in Maryland, but if Glenn must be appointed, that Reverdy Johnson should be the District Attorney— He considers it as a question between party influence and merit. After long deliberation the President postponed his decision till to-morrow. I read the draft of my answer to Addingtonupon the complaint against Porter and Gregory, which was approved— Mr. Alexander Scott paid me a long morning visit, wishing for the appointment of Agent to Guatemala, and Mr Blake of New-York, who came to obtain the appointment of judge of the middle District in Florida; which has been given to A. B. Woodward—Watkins was here all the Evening.

31. VI. A Mr Goolrick came to me with Mr Ironside— Wishing to be employed as a Messenger to carry despatches to Mr Anderson at Bogota. With the further intention of offering his military services to the Republic of Colombia— Coll. Gibson also called at the Office to recommend Goolrick— G. B. English applied again upon his project to go to Gibraltar, and wrote me a very urgent Letter to convince me of the extreme importance of this movement—which I more than doubt— Attended again at the President’s at one O’Clock with Mr Wirt— The President after further Consideration, finally concluded again to postpone the appointments for the Missions to South-America— Mr Wirt gave much at large his opinion as to the appointments of District Judge and Attorney in Maryland. Purviance and Reverdy Johnson are his favourites, and as he says excellent lawyers. But Purviance is a federalist, and Johnson a very young man. The President again said that the object of his Administration had been to draw the parties of this Country together, and unite them all as one People— But that to effect this, it was essential that he should proceed cautiously and avoiding to shock the prejudices of his own party— He still left it undecided, whom he should appoint— I met at the President’s house Mr S. L. Gouverneur the President’s son in Law— Baron Tuyll and Mr Addington called at the Office.
The Baron to thank me for the Letters I had furnished to Count Medem and Mr Addington, to take leave previous to my departure. W. LeeWyer, and Judge A. B. Woodward likewise called— Wyer dined with us, and I was occupied in the Evening with preparations for my departure.

Day. The distribution of my time differs not from that of the last Month. The bitterness and violence of Presidential electioneering increases as the time advances. The uncertainty of the event continues as great as ever. It seems as if every liar and calumniator in the Country was at work day and night to destroy my character— It does not surprize me; because I have seen the same species of ribaldry year after year heaped upon my father, and for a long time upon Washington— But it is impossible to be wholly insensible to this process while it is in operation— It distracts my attention from public business, and consumes precious time— I have finally concluded to take a Month of Holiday to visit my father, and dismiss Care.
